entry.title: Re: The sales order has already been approved, but the su...
entry.content:
Your sales‐order billing is still blocked because the flexible‐workflow that was supposed to “release” the order never completed successfully. In your Flexible Workflow Administration you see the status “Error” because the approval step ran into a runtime problem. Since the workflow didn’t finish, no work item ever landed in the approver’s inbox—and the system never removed the billing block from the order.

Why no one sees the Order in My Inbox is because, the approval step raised an error before it could resolve its agent. When agent determination fails, the work item isn’t assigned to anyone and gets flagged as an error. No valid work item → nothing shows up in the approver’s My Inbox.

Why the Billing still Blocked is because, the order header is still in “In Approval” status. As long as Approval Status ≠ Approved, billing functions (VF01/VF04 or Fiori billing apps) are locked. The incomplete workflow never toggled the standard “Release for Billing” flag.

Below are some Root‐Cause Checklist

Error Details In Flexible Workflow Administration, click the Error link for your order. Drill into the step history to see the exact failure (agent determination, authorization, missing OData service, etc.).

Agent Determination Open the Work Items without Agents app. If your order appears here, it means the system couldn’t resolve an approver. Ensure your task definitions are classified as General Task (not “Transfer Authorized”). Confirm your approver user/role is correctly assigned in Manage Teams and Responsibilities.

Activate & Validate the Scenario In Manage Workflows for Sales, verify that your workflow scenario for this document type is active and that all preconditions (value thresholds, item categories, sales org, etc.) match this order.

Runtime Environment & Jobs Run transaction SWU3 (Edit Runtime Environment) to make sure the generic workflow setup is green. Verify that the background jobs (e.g. SAP_WFRT or SAP_WIRKFLOW_SYSTEM) are scheduled and running without errors.

Authorization & OData Services Use SU53 after reproducing the error to catch missing authorizations for the workflow runtime user. Check /IWFND/ERROR_LOG for any missing or inactive OData service calls (the Fiori button “Trigger Approval” uses an OData action).

Follow the below steps to fix this and get billing moving again

  • In Flexible Workflow Administration, select the errored instance and choose Resume (after you’ve corrected the root cause).
  • Confirm that a new work item lands in My Inbox.
  • Once the approver approves, the order’s Approval Status flips to “Approved” and the billing block is removed.
  • Run your billing transaction (VF01/VF04 or the corresponding Fiori app) to create the invoice.

entry.title: Re: Bank Guarantee as noted item in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Public Cloud the classic Special G/L indicators (E = Guarantee, I = Guarantee Received) are not delivered for standard A/R or A/P processing—only down-payments (A/K) are in scope. That means you won’t find a Fiori tile “Post Bank Guarantee” or an option in “Post Incoming Payments” to pick a guarantee‐type noted item.

Public Cloud scope for Special G/L in A/R–A/P covers only down‐payments (indicators A and K). Guarantees (E or I) traditionally require on-premise SPRO customizing (OBXT, OBXS) which you cannot access in the Cloud Edition. There is no hidden Fiori app or CBC toggle to “turn on” guarantee indicators for customer/vendor line‐item management.


Some options and workarounds are:

Use a Down-Payment as Proxy
Post a down-payment request (Special G/L A or K) in the “Post Incoming Payments” (A/R) or “Post Outgoing Payments” (A/P) Fiori app. Report on open down-payments by customer or vendor to track collateral. When the guarantee is called, clear this down payment via the standard clearing process.

Leverage Treasury & Risk Management (TRM)
If your scope includes TRM (scope item FIN-TRM), you can use the Manage Bank Guarantee Fiori app: Create a Guarantee Instrument → Attach to Business Partner → Monitor expiry. This becomes a true financial instrument—separate from your subledger line items.

Custom Business Object (CBO) Extension
Extend your Cloud solution by creating a CBO “Bank Guarantee” with the fields you need. Build a simple Fiori UI to capture guarantee details and link it via Business Partner; schedule a monthly report for expiries.

If you’re not on TRM today, the fastest path is to post an A-type down-payment noted item via Post Incoming Payments (for customer collateral) or Post Outgoing Payments (for vendor collateral). Then:

  • in the Fiori app, select Special G/L Indicator = A (Customer Down-Payment) or K (Vendor Down‐Payment).
  • Enter your Bank GL Account (i.e. the “cash collateral” account) as the G/L.
  • Simulate → Post.

Use a custom report or CDS view to surface open down‐payments “held as bank guarantees,” and clear them when the guarantee expires or is called.

Currently, the LaunchPad tile is configured to open the following URL directly: https://www.concursolutions.com/.
After the user clicks the tile, the Concur login page appears, and SSO is successfully performed when the user clicks the "Sign in with SSO" button.

However, our requirement is as follows:
When a user launches Concur from the BTP LaunchPad, we want the SSO process to run automatically in the background, so that the user is taken directly to the post-login screen without needing to click anything.

Current Setup

  • SSO to Concur works correctly when initiated manually from the login page

  • LaunchPad tile URL is https://www.concursolutions.com/

Question

  • Alternatively, is there a URL pattern or configuration that can initiate the SSO flow without requiring user interaction?

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud 2508 Migration Cockpit: Material...
entry.content:
When you include the Warehouse Management Extension sheet in the standard Product migration template, the cockpit now performs an existence check against EWM‐related master data and customizing. In the 2508 release, SAP tightened this validation so that if your target system isn’t yet set up for EWM (no active EWM storage locations, no EWM product extension records), the simulation throws:

“The material <matnr> does not exist or is not activated”.

In earlier releases the cockpit silently skipped the EWM sheet; in 2508 it fails fast.

Why the other files worked Pre-2508 is because, previous releases did not validate EWM extension data at simulation. Your uploads with EWM sheets passed because the cockpit ignored the empty or incomplete EWM fields. After 2508, the cockpit enforces that if you supply an EWM‐extension row, the product must already be activated for that warehouse storage location.

Recommended approach

  • Remove EWM Extension from Product Upload. Delete or clear the Warehouse Management Extension sheet in your Excel. Run the Product migration simulation – it will succeed as before. Later, load your EWM data using the dedicated EWM migration objects.
  • Use Dedicated EWM Migration Objects. SAP provides specific migration objects for EWM master data (e.g., Warehouse Product, Storage Bins, Fixed Bins) under the “SAP EWM to Decentralized EWM” scenario. Migrate Product → then Warehouse Product via object /SCWM/MATWMGR or similar. This two-step approach keeps your core Product load separate from EWM setup.
  • Pre-Provision EWM Customizing (if you must keep EWM rows). Configure your target EWM warehouse, storage locations, and link material to EWM in Configure Your Solution before migration. Ensure the material is “activated” for EWM (via Manage Product Master Data → EWM tag). Re-run simulation; the cockpit will find the expected EWM entries and allow the Product load.

entry.title: Best practices for splitting software collections with dependency safety
entry.content:
In our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition environment, we currently group non-role-related changes (e.g., UI extensions, logic, configurations) into a single software collection due to dependency concerns.

However, since software collections cannot be released independently (no "overtaking"), we're facing a challenge where delays in a few objects block the release of all others in the same collection.

Given this, we’re looking for any practical best practices or decision rules for how to split software collections that:

  • Avoid import errors caused by object dependencies, and

  • Allow more flexible, decoupled release cycles

If anyone has defined objective rules, patterns, or decision flows for structuring collections under these constraints, I would greatly appreciate your input.

entry.title: Re: Cummulative business volume for scale basis-Settlemen...
entry.content:
Why you don’t see “Settlement Management” under SD IMG is because, in S/4HANA 2023, SAP has consolidated Settlement Management customizing into more business-centric areas rather than keeping it under classic Sales & Distribution. The “Settlement Management” IMG activities are now found under Logistics – General (not SD), or are accessed exclusively via Fiori “Manage …” apps. SAP’s official help confirms that Settlement Management is a standalone solution in S/4HANA 2023 (FPS03) and surfaces its customizing through Fiori rather than traditional SD IMG nodes.

Instead of SPRO in SD, use these Fiori apps in the SAP Fiori Launchpad (search by “Manage”)

entry.content:
My crystal report is setup as below

We are using a wrapper to call the crystal methods. We are using below method to set the csv options for crystal csv export

private CharacterSeparatedValuesFormatOptions GetCSVOptions(string formatOptions)
        {
            CharacterSeparatedValuesFormatOptions csvFormat = new CharacterSeparatedValuesFormatOptions();

            logger.Debug("getCSVOptions from " + formatOptions);

            csvFormat.has

            if (formatOptions.Equals(String.Empty))
            {
                // default CSV options
                csvFormat.Delimiter = "\"";
                csvFormat.SeparatorText = ",";
                csvFormat.ExportMode = CsvExportMode.Legacy;
                csvFormat.ReportSectionsOption = CsvExportSectionsOption.Export;
                csvFormat.GroupSectionsOption = CsvExportSectionsOption.Export;
            }
            else
            {
                string[] options = formatOptions.Split('\x01');
                csvFormat.Delimiter = options[0];
                csvFormat.SeparatorText = options[1];

                logger.Debug("csvFormat.Delimiter " + csvFormat.Delimiter);

                logger.Debug("csvFormat.SeparatorText " + csvFormat.SeparatorText);

                int option = Int16.Parse(options[2]);

                logger.Debug("option 2 " + option);
                switch (option)
                {
                    case 0:
                        csvFormat.ExportMode = CsvExportMode.Legacy;
                        break;
                    case 1:
                        csvFormat.ExportMode = CsvExportMode.Standard;
                        break;
                }

                option = Int16.Parse(options[3]);
                logger.Debug("option 3 " + option);
                switch (option)
                {
                    case 0:
                        csvFormat.ReportSectionsOption = CsvExportSectionsOption.DoNotExport;
                        break;
                    case 1:
                        csvFormat.ReportSectionsOption = CsvExportSectionsOption.Export;
                        break;
                    case 2:
                        csvFormat.ReportSectionsOption = CsvExportSectionsOption.ExportIsolated;
                        break;
                }
                
                logger.Debug("csvFormat.ReportSectionsOption " + csvFormat.ReportSectionsOption);

                option = Int16.Parse(options[4]);
                logger.Debug("option 4 " + option);
                switch (option)
                {
                    case 0:
                        csvFormat.GroupSectionsOption = CsvExportSectionsOption.DoNotExport;
                        break;
                    case 1:
                        csvFormat.GroupSectionsOption = CsvExportSectionsOption.Export;
                        break;
                    case 2:
                        csvFormat.GroupSectionsOption = CsvExportSectionsOption.ExportIsolated;
                        break;
                }

                logger.Debug("csvFormat.GroupSectionsOption " + csvFormat.GroupSectionsOption);
            }

            logger.Debug("csvformat options " + csvFormat.ToString());

            return csvFormat;
        }

And then we finally call

crReportDocument.Refresh();
                crReportDocument.Export(exportOptions);

entry.title: Re: Transfer of the HUs from Outbound to Inbound
entry.content:
Your HUs are created and packed correctly on the Outbound Delivery, but because you’re bypassing SAP’s standard lean-HU integration, the Inbound Delivery simply brings them in as extra material lines. To restore the packaging structure and unblock GR, you must either activate SAP’s lean-HU transfer logic or embed it into your custom routines.

Even without EWM, SAP can copy HUs from OD→IBD if you switch on the lean-HU integration. For that, go to SPRO → Logistics Execution → Handling Unit Management → Lean HU Integration → Set Lean HU Status Update. Create one line per Delivery‐Type pair:

  • Delivery Type (OD) = your STO GI delivery (e.g., NL or ZO)
  • Movement Type = 344/343 or 601/501 (as per inter-/intra-co)
  • Delivery Type (IBD) = your STO RI delivery (e.g., EL or ZI)
  • Tick Copy Packaging Units
  • Save and Transport.

Once in place, inbound deliveries created by standard VL01N/VL31N logic will pull in the exact HU numbers and pack structure from the outbound.

Packaging‐material lines in a two-step STO must use non-PO movement types so they’re handled as true packaging, not goods:

In SPRO → Logistics Execution → Handling Unit Management → Define Movement Types for Handling Units, map your packaging‐material item categories to the above MTs.

Ensure your OD packing uses those MTs so SAP knows these lines are packaging, not extra material.

entry.title: Re: Enable purchasing info record to be used in form temp...
entry.content:
Out of the box, the Purchase-Order and Purchase-Contract form templates in Public Cloud only understand the fields on the PO/Contract OData payload. The Purchasing Info Record (PIR) lives in a separate service—so you won’t see its fields without one of two “bridging” approaches:

  • Add custom fields on the PO/Contract item, populate them from the PIR via in-app logic, then drag them onto your form (no scripts needed).
  • Enhance your form template to call the PIR OData service at runtime (requires form-script).

Below is the easiest, fully supported way—Option 1—which avoids manual scripting entirely.

Option-1 - Custom Item Fields + In-App logic
Launch the Custom Fields and Logic app. Choose the business context:

  • Purchase Order → PurchaseOrderItem
  • Purchase Contract → PurchaseContractItem

Add new Extension: one field for each PIR attribute you need (e.g. vendor lead time, last purchase price). Make them Visible so they appear in the PO/Contract payload and can be used in forms.

In Custom fields and logic, switch to the logic side. Create a new implementation for Business Transaction Events on Purchase Order Item (e.g. event “Save” or “AfterSave”). In your ABAP/Script routine, call the standard PIR API or read table EINA/EINE for (Material, Vendor, PurchasingOrg, Plant). Write the returned PIR values into your custom fields.

Open Manage Form Templates. Select your Purchase Order or Contract template. In the Context tab, refresh so your new custom fields appear under Items. Drag/drop your extension fields into the Adobe/Word layout wherever you like. Deploy the form and test: the PO payload now carries PIR data automatically.


Option 2 (Advanced): Runtime OData Call in the Form

If you really want to pull PIR data at print time instead of pre-storing it:

In Manage Form Templates, under Data Sources, add a new OData Service - API_PurchaseInfoRecord or the relevant PIR service. Configure a parameter mapping: Material → PO-Item.Material, Vendor → PO-Header.Partner. In the form layout, write a short script to loop over the PIR collection node and bind values into your fields.

This approach keeps the PO-payload “clean” but adds complexity to your form design and maintenance.

entry.title: Re: Error in SAP portal while creating user system not ac...
entry.content:
Please refer to KBA 3146076 - What is the valid format for an S-user ID e-mail address? - SAP for Me

An S-user e-mail address has to have a certain format in order to be considered valid. A format check will be performed while adding/changing your e-mail to see if the e-mail meets the criteria. An e-mail address is considered invalid if:

  • Last character is  ; , > [ ] { }  
  • Addresses are grouped (form a@b; b@c)
  • There is no @
  • There is more than one @
  • First character of e-mail ID is a dot
  • Last character before @ symbol is a dot
  • There are 2 or more consecutive dots before @ symbol
  • There are special characters other than (.!#$%&*+/=?^_`{|}~- )before the @ symbol
  • There are spaces before and after @symbol
  • Domain is blank
  • Domain ends with dot after @ symbol
  • There is no dot after @ symbol
  • There are special characters after @ symbol (#$%&'*+/ etc.)

The email adders such as sapsupport@* will be recognized as a shared email address, thus it will not be available to create a S-user. Please use an individual email address here.

entry.title: Re: Integrate SAP Customer Checkout Mobile Orders with a...
entry.content:
Hi Fedias,

SAP Customer Checkout provides dedicated APIs for Mobile Order, and you can integrate your own Generic Payment Service Provider for payment processing.

After creating a Generic PSP in SAP Customer Checkout Manager, you can define the path to your system (e.g., a proxy you’ve developed). CCO will use this path to communicate with your backend and initiate the payment process.

From the API documentation in CCOm, you can retrieve the structure of the NotifyPaymentDTO. This DTO must be used to inform the Manager whether the payment was successful or failed. 

I've already developed 3 Generic PSPs myself, so if you need help or want to discuss integration details, feel free to reach out to me.

Best regards,
Michael Bosch
Checkout Peak

entry.title: Re: The 3 Pillars of Cloud Computing
entry.content:
Hi Community,

"

Top security practices:

  • Identity and access management: Granular control over who can access what, including multi-factor authentication.

  • Isolated environments: Client apps run in separate spaces to prevent cross-company data leaks.

  • Compliance tools: Automated auditing, logs, and controls to meet regulations like GDPR.

  • Automatic updates: The platform is always up-to-date with the latest security patches.

Client’s responsibility: Ensure secure app development practices, like input validation and permissions management."

entry.title: Extend a Custom Business Object created with Key User Extensibility using SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
This blog post covers how to setup an extension scenario from SAP S/4HANA Cloud and build Side-by-Side UI Extensions with the help of SAP Build Apps in the Business Technology Platform.

Business scenario:

A Manager wants to define business objects “Bonus Plan” for employees. A Bonus Plan is there to save employee specific rules for bonus entitlement.

Here, with Key User Extensibility, we create a custom Business Object with a data structure, logic for data initialization in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition which should have standard API operations (GET, POST, DELETE). Expose the custom business object as web service for side-by-side UI extension using Low-code No-code capabilities of SAP Build Apps. You will learn how quickly a new UI application can be developed with the no-code capabilities of SAP Build Apps. You will also find out what is the process to setup, develop and deploy a productive extension application.

Note: The maintain Bonus app shown in this blog is for educational purpose only and not meant for productive usage. It is not ensured that the data used in this extension scenario is managed in accordance with applicable legal requirements for all countries and industries and in accordance with the business needs, such as data life cycle requirements.  

Prerequisites:

  1. Subscription to SAP Build Apps on SAP BTP Sub-Account
  2. Your user needs (a) business role(s) with business catalogs Extensibility - Custom Business Objects (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_CBO), Extensibility - Custom Communication Scenarios (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_CCS) and Communication Management (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_COM) (Need to have unrestricted access if you are creating a business role and adding these catalogs).
  3. You have Created Custom Business Objects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud as per the given tutorial.                                                                

Why SAP Build Apps with SAP S/4HANA Cloud?

Create new solutions using the secure, no-code SAP Build Apps with SAP S/4HANA. Build visually and empower users to digitalise their daily work without impacting core processes. Create a personalised, accessible application that securely connects to data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

To extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud using SAP Build Apps, you can leverage side-by-side extensibility, which allows you to build extensions that run on SAP BTP and interact with your S/4HANA Cloud system. This approach enables you to create custom UIs, logic, and integrations without directly modifying the core S/4HANA Cloud system. 

 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Let’s start on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud side with the definition of the Custom Business Object and the communication settings.

Custom Business Object

In the Create Custom Business Objects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud tutorial group it is shown how to create a custom business object and generate a UI (user interface) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Expose Custom Business Object as External API

To integrate custom business object from SAP S/4HANA system with External Systems or Services like SAP Build Apps, as administrator you need to create a Communication Arrangement. You create a communication arrangement to enable the communication between your system and SAP Build App in BTP, and how they communicate. Communication Arrangement is formed by combining the below artifacts:

  1. Creating a Custom Communication Scenario
    The setup of the communication (inbound and outbound) between SAP S/4HANA and SAP BTP starts with the definition of a Custom Communication Scenario.
    The Custom Communication Scenario contains the information for both inbound and outbound HTTP-calls.
    • Open the app Custom Communication Scenarios in the Launchpad of the SAP S/4 HANA system and create a new Custom Communication Scenario with the name YY1_BONUSPLAN.

     

    • On the tab Inbound Services, you create an entry for your Custom Business Object: Press Add button to add inbound service “YY1_BONUSPLAN_CDS” and click select button. 

     

    • Press Save and Publish to finish the custom communication scenario creation.

     

  2. Creating a Communication System and User

    To enable secure communication between different systems you have to register these systems and define the user which is authorized to use the connection.

    The communication system represents the communication partner within a communication. for inbound communication, this is the external system that calls our custom Bonus plan service.

    We’ll create one Communication System for all systems that want to use our service as well as the user that they’ll have to use. If you want to access the custom BONUSPLAN OData service (Inbound) you also need to setup an authentication method. You can use several methods like e.g.., Basic Authentication, Certificate or OAuth.

    In this case we are choosing Basic Authentication for which you need to setup a Communication User. Open the app Maintain Communication Users from the Communication Management group and create there a new user with username, description, and password.

    • Open “Communication Systems” Application.
    • Start creating a new system by executing the “New” action.
    • Give following data to the new custom communication System…

    Note: you can replace XXX with your system ID.

    Field Label

    Field Value

    System ID

    EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX

    System Name

    EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX

    Host Name

    EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX

    • Scroll down to “User for Inbound Communication” and start adding one by executing the “Add” action.
    • In the Pop Up, use the value help to browse and select the user.

     

    • Choose the user you already created and then click OK. Your user for Inbound Communication is set up. Click on Save.

  3. Creating a Communication Arrangement for Custom Communication Scenario

Finally, a communication arrangement links the solution’s scenario with the Communication system and its user and exposes the Service to be used.

  • Open “Communication Arrangements” Application
  • Start creation by executing the “New” action.
  • A pop up opens in that you use the value help for Scenario first where you can select previously created Custom Communication Scenario YY1_BONUSPLAN. This will set the Scenario and default the Arrangement Name, so that you can continue the creation via “Create” button.

  • In the opening Arrangement details click to browse the Communication System
  • Choose the EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX you created before.
  • Choosing the system will automatically set the related User as well. Click Save to finish creation
  • Copy the Service URL for the next step. Here you save the inbound service URL for the destination configuration in BTP.

 

 

 

 

 


Build Side-by-Side UI Extensibility with SAP Build Apps

SAP Build Apps enables developers to implement loosely coupled extension applications securely on top of the existing SAP solution they already have. SAP Build Apps provides drag-and-drop capabilities for Citizen developers to build enterprise-grade applications confidently, authenticate and access SAP Business Technology Platform destinations. You can preview your SAP Build Apps project as web preview and can build it to deploy on SAP Build Work Zone or Android/IOS.

Here you will learn how to use SAP Build Apps, create an app that performs all the CRU (Create, Read, Update) operations for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud BONUSPLAN API for managing the Bonus Plan for the employee.

The point of this tutorial is to show you how you would perform all the CRU (Create, Read, Update) operations, and how you would handle some of the complexities of the SAP backend APIs (e.g. strict requirements for the data and handle multiple determination) for the Bonus plan scenario.

You will create an app with 2 pages:

  • Page 1: Display all Bonus plans
  • Page 2: Manage Bonus Plan, which handles Create or Update the bonus plan for employees.

Create destination to SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.   

In the SAP BTP cockpit, as administrator you need to create a destination to enable the communication to the S/4HANA Cloud system. In addition, the destination must be enabled for use in SAP Build Apps.

Procedure:

In the SAP BTP cockpit, navigate to your subaccount.

Choose Connectivity > Destination > Create Destination.

Choose Blank Template and enter the following data and click on Save.

Field

Value

Name

Enter the destination name.

Type

Select HTTP.

Description

Enter a description (SAP Build Apps to ABAP Callback Destination)

URL

Enter the Service URL saved during Communication Arrangement creation. If not saved access the communication arrangement

Proxy Type

Internet

Authentication

Select BasicAuthentication.

User

(Inbound) communication user used in the communication arrangement

Password

Set the password to the secret. Password of the (inbound) communication user used in the communication arrangement.

Additional Properties

Add the following properties:

“BuildApps.RequiresCsrf” → true

“AppgyverEnabled” → true

“HTML5.DynamicDestination ” → true

Save your entries.

 

 

 

 

 

 


Open SAP Build Apps

Open SAP Build Apps, by going to the SAP BTP cockpit, and under Instances and Subscriptions, click SAP Build Apps.

 

In the lobby of your SAP Build Apps, click Create.

 

Select Application.

 

Select Frontend and followed by this Select Web & Mobile Application and press Next button. Please note that the user needs to have access to the Custom Identity Provider to be able to create a Web & Mobile Application.

For the project name, enter Bonus plan Management and description as “Extend a key user extension from S/4HANA Cloud public edition “then click Create.

 

Connect to the REST API from the Custom Business Object on S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

In this step, you will make a connection to the BONUSPLAN API of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud system. You will enable entities: BONUSPLAN (the header for a BONUSPLAN)

  1. Go to the Integrations tab.
  2. Click Add Integration.
  3. Click BTP Destinations, and then select the destination to your SAP S/4HANA Cloud BONUSPLAN API which you have created in “Create destination to SAP S/4HANA Cloud system” section.
  4. Select Click Install Integration (upper right).
  5. Under Data Entities, scroll down so you can see both YY1_BONUSPLAN and I_Currency. For each, select it and click Enable Data Entity.
  6. You can now select an entity and click Browse Real Data to see live data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud.


  7. Click Save (upper right).



Create page for displaying BONUSPLANs (Homepage)

Now you will create the home page that displays a list of Bonus Plans, for which the user can update the existing Bonus Plan and can create a new Bonus Plan.

  • You will already have a Home Page. Click on it.
  • Click Variables → Data Variables and create a data variable based on YY1_BONUSPLAN.

 

  • Click the User Interface tab to return to the UI canvas. 
  • Add a Title field and a Text field. Set the content for the text component as “Bonus plan details” and add a button with value “Create” value and list item component.


 

 

  • Add a List Item component

 

  • Click the list item, and configure its properties as follows:

Secondary label

data item in repeat current.EmployeeID

 

Now you can test the application which should display the Bonus list by saving your changes and clicking on Preview to preview the application.

Hopefully you got this far and found success! Congratulations!!!

 

You will define the logic for the list item selection later once we finish next step (Create page for Manage Bonus Plan)

You will define the logic for the Button later once we finish next step (Create page for Manage Bonus Plan)

Create page for Manage Bonus Plan

Add logic to Add/Update Bonus Plan:

  1. Now we will add the logic to the Save button. To achieve this, click on Save button and open its logic canvas.
  2. Add logic flow functions and connect them as in the following:
  3. Configure the flow functions as follows:
  • IF condition (first): Set the condition to the following formula (validates the SAP_UUID field):
    NOT(IS_NULLY(params.SAP_UUID))

Update record: Set the following:

  • Resource name: YY1_BONUSPLAN1
  • Risk ID: page parameter SAP_UUID
  • Record: Set the following formula (allows us to make sure the integer fields receive a number value):

{ ValidityStartDate: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ValidityStartDate, ValidityEndDate: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ValidityEndDate,LowBonusAssignmentFactor: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.LowBonusAssignmentFactor,HighBonusAssignmentFactor:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.HighBonusAssignmentFactor,LowBonusPercentage_V: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.LowBonusPercentage_V, HighBonusPercentage_V:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.HighBonusPercentage_V, EmployeeID: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.EmployeeID,  EmployeeName: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.EmployeeName, TargetAmount_V:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.TargetAmount_V, TargetAmount_C:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.TargetAmount_C}

 

Create record: Set the following:

  • Resource name: YY1_BONUSPLAN1
  • Record: Set the following formula:

{ SAP_UUID: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.SAP_UUID, ValidityStartDate: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ValidityStartDate, ValidityEndDate: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ValidityEndDate,LowBonusAssignmentFactor: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.LowBonusAssignmentFactor,HighBonusAssignmentFactor:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.HighBonusAssignmentFactor,LowBonusPercentage_V: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.LowBonusPercentage_V, HighBonusPercentage_V:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.HighBonusPercentage_V, EmployeeID: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.EmployeeID,  EmployeeName: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.EmployeeName, TargetAmount_V:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.TargetAmount_V, TargetAmount_C:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.TargetAmount_C}

 

You can set the Toast and Alert flow functions for both Create record and Update record with the appropriate Text message to inform the user about the success or error message during Save.

Now you can now test the application, which is designed to display all available Bonus plans. If you select an existing Bonus Plan, the system will load all relevant field values for the chosen employee, allowing you to update those details. Additionally, you can create a new Bonus Plan by using the Create button and by following the steps mentioned in the section Test app.

Thanks, you have completed SAP Build Apps application development by extending a Custom Business Object successfully! 😊Congratulations!!!

entry.title: Re: Regarding tab control in MIR4 (ECC) *Sorry, The MIRO...
entry.content:
When you activate “Direct Posting to G/L Accounts” and “Direct Posting to Material Accounts” in IMG, you expect both the G/L Account and Material tabs to appear in MIR4. However, SAP’s screen logic treats ECC and S/4HANA differently.

1. ECC MIR4 Behavior

  • By default, standard PO-based invoice postings in ECC MIR4 hide the Material and G/L Account tabs, even if you’ve activated direct posting.
  • You only see those tabs when you pick Subsequent Debit or Subsequent Credit from the invoice dropdown: this enforces the standard GR/IR reconciliation path and prevents accidental bypass of OBYC logic.

S/4HANA MIR4 Behavior

  • In S/4HANA, SAP delivers a new screen variant for MIR4 that shows the Material tab on all invoice types once “Direct Posting to G/L & Material Accounts” is switched on.
  • The logic behind OBYC and the need for subsequent postings remains the same—it’s purely an interface simplification.

entry.title: Re: Linear Asset Management - Charcterstic Value And Desc...
entry.content:
Your Linear Data fields remain greyed out until three conditions are met:

  • the technical object (FL or Equipment) uses a Linear view profile,
  • the characteristic is flagged for Org. Area “L,” and
  • you’ve maintained header-level characteristic values in classification. Follow these steps to fix it.

Activate the Linear View Profile in SPRO > Plant Maintenance & Customer Service → Technical Objects → Functional Location → Define Category of Functional Location. For your FL category, assign the view profile LAM01 (or your custom profile that includes “Linear Data”). Likewise for equipment, go to Plant Maintenance & Customer Service → Technical Objects → Equipment → Equipment Categories → assign LAM02 as the view profile.

Flag Your Characteristics with Org. Area “L” by opening CT04 and select each characteristic used in your Linear Data tab. On the Class Types / Organizational Area section, add L (Linear Asset Management) as an Org. Area and save.

Assign Class & Maintain Header values in IL01 (Create Functional Location) or IE01 (Create Equipment) switch to the Classification tab. Assign your class (type 003 for FL, 002 for Equipment) that contains your linear characteristics. In that same tab, enter the Characteristic Values at the header level and save the object.

Then, finally, populate Linear Data by reopening your FL or Equipment in create/change mode. Go to the Linear Data tab and click Insert Row. Click into the Characteristic Description cell—your characteristics now appear in the drop-down. Enter Characteristic Value, Start Point, End Point, Length, and UoM.

In short, why this works is because, view Profile unlocks the Linear Data tab. Org. Area “L” tells SAP which characteristics apply to linear objects. Header-level values in classification populate the drop-down on the Linear Data tab.

Once all three are in place, the fields activate, and you can maintain linear measurements at equipment and FL level.

entry.title: Re: Enter a general ledger account subtype for general le...
entry.content:
It means you haven’t assigned one of the required subtypes for Cash Accounts (Type C) in your system.

In SAP S/4HANA, Type C is the new “Cash Account” category. You must pick one of the valid subtypes whenever you create a C-type G/L account:

  • B – Bank Reconciliation Account (the main account you assign to a house bank)
  • S – Subaccount (clearing account for each payment method)
  • C – Cash in Hand (petty-cash or physical cash)

For example, when you create a new bank reconciliation account in FS00, choose Type C, Subtype B; for each clearing sub-account choose Type C, Subtype S

Launch SPRO → SAP Reference IMG navigate to: Financial Accounting (New)  → General Ledger Accounting   → Master Records    → G/L Accounts     → Preparation      → Define Cash Account Subtypes

In the overview, filter for Account Type = C.

Ensure the above three entries (B, S & C) exist (and activate them if inactive). Save and transport your changes.

Finally, go to FS00 → Enter new G/L number. In Account Type, select C (Cash Account). In Subtype, press F4 and pick B, S, or C as per your need. Complete the remaining master‐data tabs and save.
Once the subtype exists in configuration, the Subtype field will no longer be blank or greyed out, and FH229 will be resolved.

entry.title: はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - データの切り替えボタンの作成
entry.content:
本ブログシリーズはSAP Analytics CloudのBI機能を使ってダッシュボードやレポートの作成を行う方を対象とし、SAP Analytics CloudのBIにおける基本の操作やTipsをハンズオン形式でご紹介します。

本ブログでは、ボタンひとつでメジャー・ディメンションを切り替えたい際にご使用いただけるデータの切り替えボタンの作成についてご紹介いたします。

 

 

目次：

  • SAP Analytics Cloudにおけるデータの切り替えボタンの概要
  • データの切り替えボタンの作成方法[ハンズオン]
    • メジャー入力コントロールの作成
    • ディメンション入力コントロールの作成

※ベースとなるサンプルストーリーの作成⼿順は、はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - サンプルモデル／ストーリーの作成 - SAP Communityでご紹介しています。
※ SAP Analytics Cloudは、四半期に１度のペースで製品のバージョンアップが実施されます。そのため今後のバージョンアップにより、本ブログで紹介する画⾯キャプチャや、操作が異なる可能性があることをご了承ください。（本ブログは2025年7⽉に作成しています。）

 

SAP Analytics Cloudにおけるデータの切り替えボタンの概要

データの切り替えボタンを使用すると、チャートで用いるメジャーやディメンションをボタンひとつで変更できる設定が可能です。「売上高のグラフをボタンひとつで営業利益のグラフに変えたい」ときや、「ディメンションを拠点別から製品別に変更したい」ときに便利です。

メジャー・ディメンションなどの用語の説明はこちら：はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - 用語入門 - SAP Community

メジャーを変更するコントロールを作成したい際はメジャー入力コントロール、ディメンションを変更するコントロールを作成したい際はディメンション入力コントロールを使用します。

 

 

データの切り替えボタンの作成方法

0. はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - サンプルモデル／ストーリーの作成 - SAP Communityで作成したストーリーを編集モードで開こう！

　0.1 ナビゲーションバーのファイルより作成したストーリーを開き、「編集」をクリックします。

 

 

1. メジャー入力コントロールを作成しよう

　1.1. 数値ポイントのチャートにメジャー入力コントロールを適用します。ビルダパネルを開きます。

 

　1.2. 一次値の「売上高」を削除します。

 

　1.3. 「少なくとも1メジャーが必要です」をクリックし、「+メジャー入力コントロールの追加」をクリックします。

 

　1.4. 利用可能なメンバーが表示されるので、チャート上で切り替えたいメジャーを選択します。今回は「すべてのメンバー」をクリックします。

 

　1.5. （任意）ディメンションが表示されるようにフィルタを伸ばします。

 

　1.6. メジャー入力コントロールを作成することができました。メジャー入力コントロールから「営業利益」を選択すると営業利益の数値ポイントが表示されていることが分かります。

 

　1.7. 同様に棒グラフにおいてもメジャー入力コントロールを作成します。

 

 

 

2. ディメンション入力コントロールを作成しよう

　2.1. 事業セグメントごとの売上高チャートにディメンション入力コントロールを適用します。ビルダパネルを開きます。

 

　2.2. ディメンションの「事業セグメント」を削除します。

 

　2.3. 「ディメンションの追加」をクリックし、「ディメンション入力コントロールの追加」を選択します。

 

　2.4. 利用可能なディメンションが表示されるので、チャート上で切り替えたいディメンションを選択します。今回は「すべてのディメンション」をクリックします。

 

　2.5. （任意）ディメンションが表示されるようにフィルタを伸ばします。

 

　2.6. ディメンション入力コントロールを作成することができました。ディメンション入力コントロールから「製品グループ」を選択すると製品グループごとの売上高が表示されていることが分かります。

 

今回はデータの切り替えボタンのご紹介でした。SAP Analytics Cloudは他にも様々な表現や便利な機能があり、本ブログシリーズでご紹介しています。はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - シリーズまとめ - SAP Communityからご参照ください。

entry.title: Re: Extending the functionality of eDocument for a non-lo...
entry.content:
Normally, when the error CE2508 triggers is if your Z-class (e.g. ZCL_DRC_EDOCUMENT) does not implement IF_EDOCUMENT_EXT_ES (required for Cloud Platform version). On fallback, it also does not implement IF_EDOCUMENT_EXT_SS (the on-premise extension interface). You registered the class under the wrong ABAP language version in EDOCOUNTRYTCH (so it tries the wrong interface).

To eliminate this error, implement the correct interface(s) in your country extension class:

  • For Cloud Public: IF_EDOCUMENT_EXT_ES
  • (Optionally) for on-premise: IF_EDOCUMENT_EXT_SS

In Fiori → Manage Your Solution → Maintain eDocument Country/Region Customizing (EDOCOUNTRYTCH), Add your country code, Set ABAP Language Version = SAP_CLOUD_PLATFORM, Enter Class = your Z-class and Activate Process Manager.

Finally, re-run your source-document posting. The cast now succeeds, and you’ll see your Financial eDocument in the cockpit.

entry.title: This Is the Way: Rethinking Analytics Orchestration with REST in SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Datasphere Task Chains have recently been enhanced with a new capability: the ability to add a REST API Step, as documented by SAP. This addition significantly expands the integration potential of Task Chains, allowing them to trigger or interact with external systems via REST APIs—something previously not possible within the task chain framework itself.

While SAP Datasphere already offers a Command Line Interface (CLI) for interacting with its environment, I believe that technical automation—especially triggering Task Chains—should be handled via REST endpoints wherever possible. (Yes, I am aware this is already on the roadmap.)

If you have followed the evolution of SAP Analytics Cloud, you have likely noticed how its REST API capabilities have grown considerably. This trend strongly suggests a broader strategic shift within SAP toward more API-driven architectures.
Beyond the technical implications, this new feature offers a glimpse into how future data and analytics architectures might be designed. The ability to call external REST APIs directly from within a Task Chain is a small yet significant change—it paves the way for loosely coupled, event-driven, and more modular system landscapes.

In this blog post, I will explore the broader implications of this feature—looking at both architectural perspectives and practical use cases—to illustrate how this seemingly simple addition might shape our thinking on modern data platform design going forward. The different implications and perspectives I will try to sketch out in this blog post.

Integration Perspective

With this new capability, you can invoke a REST service directly within a process step. What could such a REST service do? Here are a few examples:

  1. Microservices and Third-Party Data Sources - Trigger a microservice that extracts data from a third-party system and writes it into SAP Datasphere using the OPEN SQL schema.
  2.  Advanced Analytics on External Buckets - Initiate a predictive analytics process after data has been pushed to an external storage location (e.g., a Google Cloud Storage bucket), leveraging external computation power or models.
  3. Endless Possibilities - from orchestrating workflows to enriching data pipelines with external intelligence.

This simple yet powerful feature drastically lowers the barrier for integrating external systems. Especially in modern, heterogeneous IT landscapes, the ability to seamlessly interact with REST services is crucial. As solutions increasingly span multiple platforms and technologies, having native support for REST APIs within Task Chains enables more modular, scalable, and interoperable architectures.

SAC Seamless Planning Perspective

At present, Seamless Planning in SAP provides only a foundational set of features. However, even with these basic capabilities, it is now possible to trigger a Multi Action in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)—with some lightweight technical implementation, such as a microservice on SAP BTP to handle user propagation.

What Does This Enable?

It opens the door to scheduling planning-related actions that can be executed automatically—daily, during off-peak hours, or at custom intervals—all orchestrated directly from SAP Datasphere. This marks a significant step toward greater automation and operational efficiency in planning processes.

Looking ahead, the possibility of triggering a Task Chain from within a Multi Action (either via SAP’s upcoming official Task Chain Trigger feature or through a custom-built solution) would close the loop, enabling bi-directional process orchestration between SAC and Datasphere.

A Vision of Integration - Imagine this scenario:

  • Master data is loaded from an S/4HANA system into Datasphere (where the Master data may be managed in the future) and updated in the planning model.
  • Once this loading process is completed, a Data Action is automatically triggered to generate the necessary planning combinations.
  • Each step is orchestrated across systems—seamlessly integrating Datasphere and SAC.

This evolving capability points to a promising future, where SAP’s tools are moving toward more open, event-driven, and tightly connected architectures. It is a strong signal of the direction SAP is heading—toward building truly integrated, cross-platform planning and data ecosystems.

Process Orchestration

As outlined in the sections above, these new capabilities significantly enhance our ability to orchestrate analytics processes—in ways that were not possible just a few weeks ago. The integration of REST API steps and the evolving connectivity between SAP Datasphere and SAC unlocks a new level of flexibility.

What makes this particularly compelling is the ease with which we can now develop lightweight microservices on SAP BTP to support and extend these interactions. Whether it is handling authentication, user propagation, or orchestrating complex logic between systems, BTP provides a robust platform for embedding custom logic into an increasingly modular and responsive analytics architecture.

The On-Premises Thoughts

I have already referred several times to the concept of a “small microservice on SAP BTP.” This idea becomes especially relevant when you consider that SAP Datasphere is still often used alongside SAP BW, where orchestration tasks are traditionally handled via Process Chains and ABAP reports.

In many discussions—whether with internal teams or external consultants—there remains a strong inclination to implement logic directly within the ABAP stack of on-premise systems. This is understandable. It is what I would call the “home-field advantage”: familiarity, confidence, and reliability in an environment they know well. They’re certain it will work—but the question we must ask is: Will this remain a sustainable approach over the next 5 to 10 years?

The reality is that, SAP’s Business Data Cloud is on the rise, and the centrality of BW in analytics architectures is gradually diminishing. So why not embrace a more future proof approach?

By building a lightweight REST service on SAP BTP, we gain a flexible, scalable solution that can be triggered both by SAP BW and SAP Datasphere. This doesn’t just modernize our architecture—it lays the groundwork for future-proof integration patterns, better modularity, and easier maintenance in a cloud-centric world.

A broader architectural perspective

Another powerful dimension of this development is the ability to interact with a broader range of services available on SAP BTP, such as SAP Event Mesh. For example, you could emit an event to a queue and have that event trigger specific reactions among subscribed services. This pattern—similar to what has long been possible in SAP Data Intelligence using simple Pub/Sub mechanisms—enables a much cleaner, event-driven architecture that is better aligned with modern cloud-native design principles.

But this blog is not just about the “small” new feature of the REST API step. It is about what this feature represents: a clear signal of how the SAP Analytics ecosystem is rapidly evolving toward the Business Data Cloud—with SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Databricks at its core (leaving SAP BW Private Cloud Edition aside for now).

This shift demands a mindset change for analytics consultants. To remain relevant and deliver robust solutions, we must go beyond our comfort zones and understand how SAP BTP enriches this ecosystem. That includes learning how to build with CAP or UI5, orchestrate processes using SAP Build, and embrace loosely coupled, service-based thinking.

It’s no longer just about reporting and data modeling—it's about understanding how to leverage the entire BTP toolset to design smarter, more flexible processes that are fit for the future.

Conclusion

The REST API step in SAP Datasphere Task Chains is much more than a technical enhancement—it is a strategic inflection point. It pushes SAP architecture toward:

  • Greater openness and interoperability
  • Microservice- and event-driven thinking
  • Tighter orchestration between SAC, Datasphere, and BTP
  • A cleaner transition from legacy on-prem ABAP logic

The future is modular, cloud-native, and integrated—and this is your chance to start designing for it.

entry.title: Re: rule to generate Offboarding program by responsibilit...
entry.content:
Hi @mohammadshoaib 

To generate offboarding tasks for assets across your legal entities such as Finance or Admin, SAP recommends you take the following approach:

  • You should set up a “Select Offboarding Task Config” rule in your admin center, with explicit “if/else rules for every legal entity and responsibility group.
  • After that, create offboarding task Configurations for each group mentioned above in every legal entity, assign desired tasks to the relevant Responsible Group.
  • Follow up with confirming that each group has been assigned the appropriate role permissions to ensure they can access and complete the designated tasks.
  • Finally test these with sample offboarding scenarios and ensure to adjust rules or permissions as desired. Please take note that some tasks might still not generate, if this happens, verify that each If/Else branch is present, groups have permissions, and assignees are properly set.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Project Kernseife - improving the measurement of Clean Core in ABAP
entry.content:
Hi Patrick

let me, as the Developer behind Kernseife, answer this:
Unfortunatly it is not possible to use Kernseife in in ABAP BTP (I guess, that's what you mean by ABAP Cloud).
The Standard Check we are based on and related objects are not C1 ABAP Cloud released. (and yes, we are aware that it is kinda ironic that a Clean Core Tool is not fully Clean Core compliant :))
In ABAP Cloud there is a new framework to build ATC Checks with released classes and interfaces, but those have limitations which make it impossible for us to implement Kernseife in it (which is "proven" by the fact, that also the Standard ATC Check for Usage APIs is not using them).
We would be really happy to bring Kernseife to ABAP BTP, as its role/usage as a Central ATC Check Instance is really nice, but unfortunatly at the moment this is not possible.

Regarding to your exemption questions, I'm not sure if I understand it properly.
Yes, you can run the check on a specific object (e.g. Class) and only get findings inside that class.
Exemptions are possible on 3 Levels (Package, Object and Finding), that is all ATC standard functionality.
But you can't exempt the usage of one object (e.g. Exempt Usage of a FUNC whereever it is used).
That's were you can change the classificatfion in Kernseife and have it rated differently so there are no Prio 1/2 findings anymore.
Kernseife is only checking the "usage" of Objects.
If you mean, if we can use Kernseife Classifications to also allow ABAP Language stuff based on objects, no, that is not possible as this is a different check. Not sure what the Intention would be behind that?

Regards,
Daniel

entry.title: Breaking Free from Legacy Distribution: How SAP SDM Delivers 90% Business Coverage Out-of-the-Box
entry.content:
Breaking Free from Legacy Distribution: How SAP SDM Delivers 90% Business Coverage Out-of-the-Box



Your secondary distribution operations face mounting pressure. Manual dispatch coordination consumes valuable time while delivery schedules struggle to adapt to changing demands. Legacy systems require extensive customizations that compromise SAP upgrades and inflate IT costs. Route planning relies on experience rather than optimization algorithms, leading to suboptimal fuel consumption and vehicle utilization. 

The oil and gas industry demands better solutions. Modern distribution networks require real-time visibility, automated decision-making, and seamless integration with existing SAP infrastructure. Traditional approaches of building custom solutions or heavily modifying core SAP functionality create technical debt that becomes increasingly expensive to maintain.

SAP SDM: Purpose-Built for Downstream and BULK logistics 

SAP SDM (S4SCSD) , developed by Implico  as part of SAP S/4HANA Supply Chain for Secondary Distribution, addresses the specific requirements of oil and gas secondary distribution. The solution covers approximately 90% of best practice business processes out of the box, significantly reducing implementation effort and operational costs. 

SDM operates within SAP's Business Technology Platform architecture, maintaining clean core principles while delivering industry-specific functionality. This approach eliminates the traditional trade-off between operational capability and system maintainability that has plagued oil companies for years. 

Automated Dispatch Management 

The system automates dispatch planning by evaluating customer orders, inventory positions, vehicle capacity, and delivery constraints. Dispatch teams can generate optimized schedules in minutes rather than hours, with the system considering factors such as product compatibility, regulatory requirements, and driver availability. 

Compartment planning functionality optimizes vehicle loading by analyzing product specifications, contamination risks, and cleaning requirements. The system maximizes vehicle utilization while ensuring product integrity and regulatory compliance. 

Intelligent Route Optimization 

SDM incorporates advanced routing algorithms that consider traffic patterns, delivery windows, vehicle specifications, and driver regulations. The system creates routes that minimize transportation costs while maintaining service levels. Integration with GPS and telematics systems provides real-time delivery tracking and enables proactive customer communication. 

When disruptions occur, the system automatically recalculates optimal routes and updates stakeholders. This capability reduces the manual effort required for exception management while improving customer satisfaction. 

Clean Core Implementation Benefits 

SDM's product architecture preserves your SAP clean core strategy. The solution is based on best practice processes and requires no modifications to standard SAP functionality, ensuring smooth upgrades and reduced maintenance overhead.  

Customer-specific requirements can be solved using SAP in-app or side by side extensibilities without modifying the standard code. Your IT organization gains powerful downstream capabilities without compromising system stability or long-term flexibility. 

Implementation typically requires 3-6 months compared to 12-18 months for traditional custom development approaches. Pre-configured integration points for terminal automation, tank gauging, and laboratory systems eliminate common integration challenges that extend project timelines. 

Measurable Business Impact 

Organizations implementing SDM report implementation cost reductions of 40-60% compared to custom development. Operational improvements include dispatch planning time reductions of 70%, improved on-time delivery performance, and decreased safety stock level through better demand forecasting. 

The solution includes built-in compliance frameworks for transportation, environmental, and safety regulations. A capability that reduces manual oversight requirements while ensuring adherence to industry standards. 

Demand Forecasting and Distribution Planning 

SDM analyzes historical consumption patterns, seasonal variations, and market trends to generate accurate demand forecasts. The system considers inventory availability, supplier lead times, and customer requirements to optimize distribution planning. This functionality reduces stockouts while minimizing inventory carrying costs. 

Sales order automation streamlines the creation of quotations, orders, and invoices. The system integrates with customer portals and mobile applications to provide self-service capabilities that reduce administrative overhead. 

Implico Partnership Advantage 

Implico brings four decades of experience in liquid goods distribution and oil and gas retail operations. Their specialized knowledge ensures SDM addresses real-world operational challenges rather than theoretical requirements. The company's holistic consulting approach includes business process optimization, change management, and comprehensive knowledge transfer. 

Implico's quality assurance program provides structured implementation methodology that minimizes project risk. Their team understands the complexities of oil and gas and liquid management  operations and can navigate the unique challenges that arise during system deployment. 

Strategic Implementation Considerations 

SDM enables oil and gas companies to modernize distribution operations without disrupting core SAP functionality. The solution provides immediate operational benefits while maintaining long-term system flexibility. Pre-configured processes address the majority of secondary distribution requirements, allowing your team to focus on optimization rather than basic functionality development. 

Market conditions and regulatory pressures require efficient distribution operations. SDM provides the technology foundation to compete effectively while managing costs. The solution's industry-specific design eliminates the compromises typically required when adapting generic supply chain tools to oil and gas operations. 

Your distribution network can benefit from intelligent automation and real-time visibility. SDM delivers these capabilities through proven SAP technology while maintaining the clean core principles essential for long-term success. 
 
For more information about how SAP SDM can optimize your secondary distribution operations while maintaining clean core architecture, contact Implico to discuss your specific requirements and implementation approach.

entry.title: Re: Mass deletion of MARD entries for a specific storage...
entry.content:
SAP Note 543279 (“MM_MATNR: Execution for Specific Organizational Levels”) extends the standard MM_MATNR archive object by adding organizational‐level selection fields—such as plant, storage location, sales organization, distribution channel, warehouse, and storage type—to the archive write program’s selection screen. This enhancement lets you zero in on exactly the segments you want to archive, rather than processing all flagged materials across every organizational unit.

In short, how the above note helps to narrow archiving scope is

  • Adds storage location as a filter field on the MM_MATNR archiving variant.
  • Ensures only those materials flagged for deletion at that storage location are picked up.
  • Lets you leave deletion flags in other storage locations untouched, so only your external warehouse entries get archived.

Implementing the note means your MM71/MMREO050 run can target MARD records for a single storage location, reducing collateral deletion risk.

Key Considerations & Limitations

  • The note only enhances the selection screen; it does not change the underlying deletion logic of the MM_MATNR object. If dependencies exist (open POs, reservations, stock, etc.), those records will still be skipped by standard checks.
  • Archiving still operates on the material‐master hierarchy: even with a storage location filter, the object processes the material at plant level under the hood. You need to verify that MARD segments get cleaned independently of MARC/MARA.
  • Applying OSS notes requires system preparation (SNOTE download, counterparts, transport, and testing).
  • Extensive testing in a non‐production environment is critical to confirm that only the intended MARD entries are actually archived and physically deleted.

With the above, one questions comes to your mind; that is "Is it a viable solution". The answer is Yes if your primary goal is to archive/delete only the storage location segment (MARD) for one warehouse, Note 543279 is a legitimate way to fine‐tune the MM_MATNR archiving selection. It’s fully SAP-supported and much safer than direct‐table deletes. However, because it doesn’t alter the archiving logic itself, you must:

  • Flag your target MARD entries (via MM17/MASS or a custom ABAP).
  • Apply Note 543279 to your archive variant to include storage location as a selection parameter.
  • Run MM71/MMREO050 in test mode first to ensure only those MARD rows are processed.
  • Review logs for skipped records due to dependencies before moving to a productive run.

entry.title: Re: How can we create a UI DEEP link for a Custom Non Use...
entry.content:
Hi @Ayaz 

Thank you for your question.

SAP’s official help and KBAs for SuccessFactors Public Cloud confirms that it is not currently possible to deep link directly to a custom UI for a non-user-based custom MDF object. The deep link functionality only supports navigation to the standard Manage Data screen or People Profile block if configured for user objects.

SAP recommends linking to the Manage Data screen for your custom object or exposing the relevant access on the SuccessFactors Home Page via portlets. Please note, this will not open your custom UI screen. If you require direct deep links to a custom form or UI, the best approach is to submit an enhancement request to SAP.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: IN KE5Z REPORT KRW IS NOT REPORTING CORRECTLY
entry.content:
FI uses table TCURX (transaction OY04) to determine how many decimals each currency has.   For KRW, SAP delivers zero decimals. Controlling (PCA) also reads TCURX—but then applies its own scaling when displaying line items via KE5Z. If TCURX has a stray entry for KRW set to “2” decimals, KPI in PCA will multiply your 82 million by 10^2 → 8.2 billion.

What you need to do is Run OY04 → search for currency KRW → ensure Decimal places = 0 (no entry = default 2; explicit 0 = zero). Synchronize TCURX between your FI and controlling clients; transport the correct entry.

In SPRO under Controlling → Profit Center Accounting → Basic Settings → Currencies, you define which currency types (0 = local, 1 = group, etc.) PCA reports on. If your controlling‐area currency type for “Local Currency” has been inadvertently set to use a 2-decimal precision, KE5Z will scale up by 10^2.
So go to SPRO → Controlling → Profit Center Accounting → Basic Settings → Currencies. Verify 0-decimal precision for the “Local Currency” entry of your controlling area. Transport and re‐execute KE5Z.

KE5Z allows you to define scale factors (units, thousands, millions) per report variant in customizing. A variant configured with “Scale = 100” or “Digits = 2” will multiply all displayed values by 100. So go to SPRO → Controlling → Profit Center Accounting → Information System → Reports → Line Item Reports → Define Scaling Factors. Find the variant used by KE5Z → ensure Scale Factor = 1 (no scaling). Re‐run KE5Z with the corrected variant.

On the KE5Z selection screen, you choose a Currency Type (Document, Local, Group). Selecting “Group Currency” can introduce unexpected decimal handling if your group currency differs. On your KE5Z screen, set Currency Type = 0 (Local Currency), Confirm the Currency Code = KRW and execute and compare to RAABGA01.

entry.content: For 1) As mentioned on the page and in the SAP DEVELOPER LICENSE AGREEMENT 3.2. license the resources on https://tools.hana.ondemand.com/#sapui5 are only to be installed on a personal workstation for offline development but not for running SAPUI5 apps in any productive scenario. This is only allowed on a SAP server. So you would need any SAP onPremise system that contains SAPUI5 to run your app in an offline network.

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud ALM: requirement approval with external workflow management system
entry.content: @NagaSiva  might this be a problem with the Destination for the BPA? I would to encourage you to check your URLs there

entry.title: Re: 2025 Q3 SAP Analytics Cloud compass Highlights
entry.content:
Hi expert, 
I'm new to the Compass. I also research and understand the concept of Monte Carlo simulation. But the question is: If I have a probability, then what to do next? For instance, the Profit is calculated by Profit = Revenue - COGS - Discount, the target for my Profit is 9M and the probability generated by Compass is 55%, so how can I choose Revenue, COGS and Discount for my planning to achieve the target?
Hope you a nice workng day!
Regards,
Hieu Nguyen

entry.title: API Inbound Delivery SAP_COM_0224 API Error deliveryrequest_in
entry.content:
Currently Im trying to implement the Indbound delivery as SOAP API SAP_COM_0224. 

 

sap-vdm-sot-InboundDelivery-v1

 

https://api.sap.com/api/DELIVERYREQUEST_IN/overview

 

When trying to Create a Inbound delivery using the Tool SOAP UI i always get Tons of Error messages like "Authorizationd denied" and "Wrong SOAP Version" 

 

At this moment i did try it all. SOAP V1.1, SOAP 1.2 with there according SAOP envelopes. 

 

This is our endpoint: https://myXXXXXX-api.s4hana.cloud.sap/sap/bc/srt/scs_ext/sap/deliveryrequest_in?MessageId=916C6E5X-3BB2-11CA-A054-08002B1BB6K9 

Neither the S/4 Error Messages nor the Documentation of api.sap.com help me at this point. therefore i was creating the Ticket. 

Do i miss anything?

This is my preferred Payload:

entry.title: Re: Issue with assignment of right Inspection Plan to Lot
entry.content:
Hi,

Looks like your setup should work, but maybe check some data in the header: usage & status, the validity dates of the group number plans, the lot size of the group number plans, if the material-vendors combination is assigned to the different group number plans. Assume that the DMR criteria in the plan & quality levels will be per material & vendor (to check per vendor which receipts need to be inspected) and not per manufacturer.

greetings, Herman

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud ALM: requirement approval with external workflow management system

entry.title: Re: Fixing Headers & Footers while generating Documents i...
entry.content:
Hi @hiren_6374 

Thank you for raising this issue.

Please note that the Employee Central Document Generation does not currently support fixed headers and footers on every page of a multi-page letter. When a document's content changes or expands, the system may move headers and footers from their intended positions due to the way page breaks are designed or implemented.

However, it is recommended to embed headers or footers as images at the top and bottom of your template. Note that these will only appear once per document and may not remain at the top or bottom on any other subsequent pages. At the moment, there is no configuration or scripting workaround available for true per page headers or footers in EC Document Generation.

Consider submitting an enhancement request via the SAP Influence portal if this limitation heavily impacts your organisation. Alternatively, you may consider external document generation and upload as a workaround.

2423967 - Header and Footer in Document Generation-EC

Enabling and Updating Header and Footer Fields

Organization-Based Email Notification Header and Footer

I hope this provides more clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: RAP: Which Activity (ACTVT) should be used in Access Control for Access Category "Value Help/F4"
entry.content:
Hi all,

in an Authorization Object in ABAP Cloud the Activities are mapped to one of the three Categories "Read", "Write", "Value Help".

The Categories are used in Business catalogs (where "Value Help" is labeled as "F4"), Role/Role Template Assignments, etc.

For Activities there are standard values (see eg onpremise in tables acl_actvt/acl_actvtt): 01 for Create, 02 for Change, 03 for Display, 08 for Delete

03 maps to Access Category Read

01,  02, 08 maps to Write

But there is no obvious activity value for Access Category "Value Help".

What activity do you use for Value Help?

Thanks for suggestions, pointers to documentation, tutorials, etc!

Regards,

  Wolfgang

entry.title: Re: How to created claims in BenefitEmployeeClaim via API ?
entry.content:
Hi @rezadwi 

My understanding is that the Benefit Employee Claim object in SAP SuccessFactors is read-only via standard API interfaces. That means it allows only retrieval of claim data but not the creation or update. Employees must submit claims using the Employee Central interface, and claims are then stored in the Benefit Employee Claim object. Please note that there is no supported API endpoint to directly create claims from your inhouse app, nor is there one to store claims in this object programmatically.

For similar automation, you may consider using SAP SuccessFactors Integration Center, custom MDF objects, or certified third-party solutions. However, note that these do not update the standard claim object directly due to system restrictions.

You can submit a business requirement or enhancement request to SAP if direct API-based claim creation into EC Global is a requirement to your organisation.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris
